title: Do teachers favour intelligent students? - Quora

response.answer_text: I favor efficient students. If there is one thing I despise then it’s explaining one thing 2+ times when I’ve explained it twice for the whole class and you just didn’t feel like listening. I will leave you hanging for not paying attention - you are literally wasting time. Oh no, not my time. But yours and your classmates’ time. Honestly, maybe you should start by actually reading the question and trying to think for a change. I’m not your mother that I must literally spell it out for you and I won’t, either, unless I’m at my wits end. Intelligent means capable of learning. Perhaps I do favor students that are capable of learning. I mean, if you aren’t, then your place isn’t in public school but somewhere more specialized to teach you important life skills so you can maximize your independence. If this is not your case, then I suppose you are intelligent as in capable of learning. I favor students who are polite and respect other people’s right to study in a calm and safe environment. Just because you don’t enjoy it doesn’t mean you get to ruin it for everybody else. That’s violence and bullying and I will not stand for it. If you don’t feel like you have a talent for it, then news flash, talent means nothing. Begin by making an effort, and sooner or later you will be good at it if you let yourself. It’s not about talent, talent is brushing off responsibility, and if it comes easy, you’re not really learning.

This actually depends more on the personality of that “intelligent” student. However for me it comes across that they are somehow - I wouldn’t call it in favour - “like” the student more. If the student have let’s say a quiet personality (I think) the teachers have this mind set that they wouldn’t cause any trouble so they always tries to be nicer to those students. I also notice that some teachers tend to either call on intelligent students or just ignore their raised hands completely until there is no other hands up (sometimes they just answer the question themselves).

They probably appreciate them a bit more but they want to help students learn new things. Some like the challenge that students who struggle and then they see the recognition in their eyes when they finally understand. I suppose there are some who do and some who do not. It all depends on the motivation of the teacher.

It’s kind of hard to tell because I don’t know every single teacher in this world, and if I were to ask them, I wouldn’t know if they were telling the truth. But those who do only favor intelligent students should not be teaching.
